page.title: 3.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will explore how a linear model is used to describe the relationship between two numerical variables and how to use a line of best fit to make predictions.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the rate of change and \(y\)-intercept for a linear model in everyday language.
  • Draw a linear model that fits the data well and use the linear model to estimate values.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 3.1.1: Exploring Scatter Plots
  • 3.1.2: Creating a Scatter Plot Using Data
  • 3.1.2: Self Check 
  • 3.1.3: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Linear Model
  • 3.1.3: Self Check 
  • 3.1.4: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Scatter Plot
  • 3.1.4: Self Check 
  • 3.1.5: Using an Equation for a Fit Line 

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 3.1.6: Practice
  • 3.1.7: Summary

page.title: 3.1.1: Exploring Scatter Plots
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

What do you notice? What do you wonder?

\(y = 1.5x+22.7\)


Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

Things you may notice:

  • More people generally means more noise.
  • At around 65,000 people, there are three different noise levels.
  • The equation of the line is given.

Things you may wonder:

  • Where is the origin?
  • Why are all the points not on the line?
  • What can we do with this?

page.title: 3.1.2: Creating a Scatter Plot Using Data
page.contents:
Activity

Watch the following video to help you answer the questions below.




  1. Record the weight for the number of oranges in the box from the video.

number of oranges

weight in kilograms

3

4

5

6

7

8

9

10


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

number of oranges

weight in kilograms

3

1.027

4

1.162

5

1.502

6

1.617

7

1.761

8

2.115

9

2.233

10

2.569

 



  1. Create a scatter plot of the data.

Use the graphing tool here. Then select the Solution button to check your work.



3. Draw a line through the data that fits the data well.

Use the graphing tool here.. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

\(y=0.216x+0.345\)



4. Estimate a value for the slope of the line that you drew. What does the value of the slope represent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer: 

About 0.2. The value represents the approximate weight of each orange added to the box.


5. Estimate the weight of a box containing 11 oranges. Will this estimate be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 2.8 kilograms \((2.6+0.2=2.8)\). The estimate should be close to the actual value since there is only 1 additional orange added, and while there is some variability, it is not great.




6. Estimate the weight of a box containing 50 oranges. Will this estimate be close to the actual value? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 10.6 kilograms \((2.6+40⋅0.2=10.6)\). This estimate will probably not be very close. With data only going to 10 oranges, the variability in orange weight will make it harder to get an estimate that is close to the actual value with more oranges. 




7. Estimate the coordinates for the vertical intercept of the line you drew. What might the \(y\)-coordinate for this point represent?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

About 0.3 kilogram. The \(y\)-coordinate estimates the weight of the box with no oranges in it.



8. When you use a linear model to estimate a value in the data given in a scatter plot, that is called interpolation. When you use a linear model to estimate the value outside the data given in the scatter plot, that is called extrapolation.

Which point(s) are best fit by your linear model? How did you decide?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When there were 6 oranges in the basket, it was closest to my line. I decided this because the line almost goes through that point.




9. Which point(s) fit the least well by your linear model? How did you decide?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

When there were 7 oranges in the basket, it was the worst estimate. I decided this since this point is the farthest from the line.



Compare your line with that of a partner. Discuss why you chose to put your lines where you did. How are your answers different? Which of you has a line that is the better fit? Why?

page.title: 3.1.2: Self Check
page.contents:
The plot below is a scatter plot of mean temperature in July and mean inches of rain per year for a sample of midwestern cities. A line is drawn to fit the data. 

Use the line provided to predict the mean number of inches of rain per year for a city that has a mean temperature of 70°F in July.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Go to 70 on the \(x\)-axis and see where the value meets the line. The answer is 33.5 inches per year.
That’s correct! Check yourself: At 70 degrees on the \(x\)-axis, the value the line crosses is approximately 33.5 inches per year.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Go to 70 on the \(x\)-axis and see where the value meets the line. The answer is 33.5 inches per year.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Go to 70 on the \(x\)-axis and see where the value meets the line. The answer is 33.5 inches per year.

page.title: 3.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Drawing and Interpreting Scatter Plots

A scatter plot is a graph of plotted points that may show a relationship between two sets of data. If the relationship is from a linear model or from a model that is nearly linear, the professor can draw conclusions using his knowledge of linear functions.

Here is an example of a scatter plot.



Notice this scatter plot does not indicate a linear relationship. The points do not appear to follow a trend. In other words, there does not appear to be a relationship between the age of the student and the score on the final exam.

Example: Using a Scatter Plot to Investigate Cricket Chirps

The table shows the number of cricket chirps in 15 seconds for several different air temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. 


Chirps

44

35

20.4

33

31

35

18.5

37

26

Temperature

80.5

70.5

57

66

68

72

52

73.5

53

Plotting these data suggests that there may be a trend. We can see from the trend in the data that as the number of chirps increases every 15 seconds, the temperature increases. The trend appears to be roughly linear, though certainly not perfectly so.



Once we recognize a need for a linear function to model that data, the natural follow-up question is: “What is that linear function?” One way to approximate our linear function is to sketch the line that seems to best fit the data. Then we can extend the line until we can verify the \(y\)-intercept. We can approximate the slope of the line by extending it until we can estimate the \(\frac{rise}{run}\).

Continuing the Example: Finding a Line of Best Fit

Find a linear function that fits the data above by “eyeballing” a line that seems to fit.

On a graph, we could try sketching a line. Using the starting and ending points of our hand-drawn line, points \((0, 30)\) and \((50, 90)\), this graph has a slope of \(m\;=\;\frac{60}{50}\;=\;1.2\) and a \(y\)-intercept at 30. 

The slope means that for every increase of 1 chirp per 15 seconds, the temperature increases 1.2 degrees. 

The \(y\)-intercept stands for the temperature needed for crickets to start chirping.



Different methods of making predictions are used to analyze data. The method of interpolation involves predicting a value inside the domain and/or range of the data. The method of extrapolation involves predicting a value outside the domain and/or range of the data.

Model breakdown occurs at the point when the model no longer applies.

Continuing the Example: Understanding Interpolation and Extrapolation

Use the cricket data from the table to answer the following questions:

    1. Would predicting the temperature when crickets are chirping 30 times in 15 seconds be interpolation or extrapolation? Make the prediction and discuss whether it is reasonable.
    2. Would predicting the number of chirps crickets will make at 40 degrees be interpolation or extrapolation? Make the prediction and discuss whether it is reasonable.

Solution:

  1. The number of chirps in the data provided varied from 18.5 to 44. A prediction at 30 chirps per 15 seconds is inside the domain of our data, so it would be interpolation. Using our model:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}T(30)&=&30+1.2(30)\\&=&66\;degrees\end{array}\)

Based on the data we have, this value seems reasonable.


  1. The temperature values varied from 52 to 80.5. Predicting the number of chirps at 40 degrees is extrapolation because 40 is outside the range of our data. Using our model:

\(\begin{array}{rcl}40\;&=&\;30\;+\;1.2c\\10\;&=&\;1.2c\\c\;&\approx&\;8.33\end{array}\)

We can compare the regions of interpolation and extrapolation using the following figure.

Try It: Drawing and Interpreting Scatter Plots

The scatter plot below shows the height and speed of some of the world’s fastest roller coasters. A linear model was drawn to fit the data.


What would you expect the speed to be for a roller coaster that is 350 feet tall?

Enter your answer here.

Here is how to find the estimate of the speed:

Looking at the linear model, when the height on the \(x\)-axis is 350 feet, the value meets the line at approximately 98 mph. Since this is an estimate, you may have an answer close to 98, but it should be closer to 100 mph than 95 mph based on the graph.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.1.3: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Linear Model
page.contents:
Activity

The scatter plot shows the sale price of several food items, \(y\), and the cost of the ingredients used to produce those items, \(x\), as well as a line that models the data. The line is also represented by the equation \(y = 3.48x + 0.76\).

  1. What is the predicted sale price of an item that has ingredients that cost $1.50? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

$5.98 from the equation \((3.48⋅1.5+0.76=5.98)\), or approximately $6 from the scatter plot graph



  1. What is the predicted ingredient cost of an item that has a sale price of $7? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

$1.79 from the equation \(\left(\frac{7-0.76}{3.48}\;=\;1.79\right)\), or approximately $1.75 from the scatter plot graph



  1. What is the slope of the linear model? What does that mean in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

3.48. This means that for every extra dollar spent on ingredients, the sale price of the food item is expected to increase by about $3.48.



  1. What is the \(y\)-intercept of the linear model? What does this mean in this situation? Does this make sense?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

0.76. This means that a food item that is made with free ingredients would still be sold for approximately 76 cents. Sample responses:

  • This doesn’t seem to make sense because something that is free to make should not cost anything for the customer.
  • This might make sense since it would still cost some money to either run the machines or pay the people to make the item.



Video: Using Linear Models

Watch the following video to learn more about how to use linear models.

page.title: 3.1.3: Self Check
page.contents:
The scatter plot below shows the age (in years) and the price (in dollars) of used compact cars advertised in the local newspaper.


Nora drew a line to fit the data. What is the slope of her line, and what does it mean in the problem?

answer.answer_text: \(-1000\), for every year older the car is, its price decreases 1000 dollars.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope is negative, and if the points \((13,6000)\) and \((7, 12000)\) are used, the slope is \(\frac{12000-6000}{7-13}\;=\;-\;\frac{6,000}6\;=\;-1000\)

answer.answer_text: \(1000\), for every year older the car is, its price decreases 1000 dollars.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope of the line is negative, and the price decreases as the cars get older. The answer is the slope is \(-1000\). For every year older the car is, its price decreases 1000 dollars.

answer.answer_text: \(1000\), for every year older the car is, its price increases 1000 dollars.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope of the line is negative, and the price decreases as the cars get older. The answer is the slope is \(-1000\). For every year older the car is, its price decreases 1000 dollars.

answer.answer_text: \(-\frac1{1000}\), for every year older the car is, it decreases \(\frac1{1000}\) of its value the year before.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: To find slope, use the change of the \(y\)-values over the change of the \(x\)-values, or rise over run. For every year older the car is, its price decreases 1000 dollars.

page.title: 3.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Interpreting a Linear Model

The scatter plot below shows the height and speed of some of the world’s fastest roller coasters. A line has been drawn to show a good fit for the data. 



The equation of the line drawn is \(S= 0.11h +60\).

What does this slope mean in the problem?

For every foot taller the roller coaster is, the speed increases 0.11 miles per hour.

Try It: Interpreting a Linear Model

Eight students were asked to estimate their score on a 10-point quiz. Their estimated and actual scores are given in the table below. Plot the points. Then sketch a line that fits the data. 

  1. Tell what you would expect someone’s grade to actually be if they predicted their grade to be a 5 out of 10.
  2. What does the slope mean in this problem?

Predicted

Actual

6

6

7

7

7

8

8

8

7

9

9

10

10

10

10

9

Here are the points from the table plotted on a scatter plot, with the \(x\)-axis being the predicted scores and the \(y\)-axis being the actual scores.


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to answer these questions using the linear model:

  1. Using the linear model above, if a student predicted a 5 on the quiz, they should have an actual score of 6.
  2. The slope is the change in the actual grade point for each predicted grade point.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.1.4: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Scatter Plot
page.contents:
Activity

Here are several scatter plots.

  1. \(y=-9.25+400\)


  1. \(y=0.44x + 0.04\)


  1. \(y = 4x+87\)


  1. \( y= -2.4x + 25.0\)



  1. Using the horizontal axis for \(x\) and the vertical axis for \(y\), interpret the slope of each linear model in the situations shown in the scatter plots.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  • Scatter Plot A: For every increase in age of one year, the linear model estimates that the reaction time decreases by about 9.25 milliseconds.
  • Scatter Plot B: For every additional banana, the linear model estimates that the price increases by about $0.44.
  • Scatter Plot C: For each additional square foot, the linear model estimates that the cost to install flooring increases by about $4.
  • Scatter Plot D: For every increase in temperature of 1 degree Celsius, the linear model estimates that the volume decreases by about 2.4 cubic centimeters.

  1. If the linear relationship continues to hold for each of these situations, interpret the \(y\)-intercept of each linear model in the situations provided.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  • Scatter Plot A: The reaction time estimated by the linear model for a newborn is 400 milliseconds.
  • Scatter Plot B: The price estimated by the linear model for purchasing zero bananas is $0.04.
  • Scatter Plot C: The fixed cost to install flooring is $87.
  • Scatter Plot D: 25 cubic centimeters is the volume estimated by the linear model for a temperature of zero degrees Celsius.


Clare, Diego, and Elena collect data on the mass and fuel economy of cars at different dealerships. 

Clare finds the line of best fit for data she collected for 12 used cars at a used car dealership. The line of best fit is \(y=\frac{-9}{1000}x+34.3\), where \(x\) is the car’s mass, in kilograms, and \(y\) is the fuel economy, in miles per gallon.

Diego made a scatter plot for the data he collected for 10 new cars at a different dealership.


Elena made a table for data she collected on 11 hybrid cars at another dealership.

mass

(kilograms)

fuel

economy

(miles per gallon)

1,100

38

1,200

39

1,250

35

1,300

36

1,400

31

1,600

27

1,650

28

  1. Interpret the slope and \(y\)-intercept of Clare’s line of best fit in this situation.
  2. Diego looks at the data for new cars and used cars. He claims that the fuel economy of new cars decreases as the mass increases. He also claims that the fuel economy of used cars increases as the mass increases. Do you agree with Diego’s claims? Explain your reasoning.
  3. Elena looks at the data for hybrid cars and correctly claims that the fuel economy decreases as the mass increases. How could Elena compare the decrease in fuel economy as mass increases for hybrid cars to the decrease in fuel economy as mass increases for new cars? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers:

  1. The slope means that the fuel economy decreases 9 miles per gallon for every 1,000 kg increase in mass. The \(y\)-intercept represents the fuel economy of a car, in miles per gallon, that has a mass of 0 kg.
  2. Diego’s claim about new cars is correct. You can look at the graph and see that the fuel economy tends to decrease as the mass increases because the scatter plot appears to have a negative slope. Diego’s claim about used cars is not correct because the line of best fit has a negative slope, which means that the fuel economy decreases as the mass increases.
  3. Elena needs to compare the slope of the data for hybrids to the slope of the data for new cars. She could do this by looking at the scatter plots and graphing an approximated line of best for each scatter plot. She could then see which line of best fit looks like it is decreasing faster or find and compare the slopes of each approximated line of best fit.

page.title: 3.1.4: Self Check
page.contents:
The scatter plot below shows the results of a survey of eighth-grade students who were asked to report the number of hours per week they spend playing video games and the typical number of hours they sleep each night.




Which of the following conclusions can you make looking at the data?

answer.answer_text: As video game time increases, sleep time increases.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Notice the slope of the line is negative. As the line goes farther right, the line goes down. The answer is as video game time increases, sleep time decreases.

answer.answer_text: As video game time decreases, sleep time decreases.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: As the line goes farther right, the line goes down. The answer is as video game time increases, sleep time decreases.

answer.answer_text: As video game time increases, sleep time decreases.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: As the number of hours spent on video games increases, the line goes down, so the amount of sleep time decreases.

answer.answer_text: There is not a trend between time spent on video games and sleep time.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: There is a linear model to the data points. The answer is as video game time increases, sleep time decreases.

page.title: 3.1.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Using Linear Models

The Monopoly board game is popular in many countries. The scatter plot below shows the distance from “Go” to a property (in number of spaces moving from “Go” in a clockwise direction) and the price of the properties on the Monopoly board. The equation of the line is \(P = 8x + 40\), where \(P\) represents the price (in Monopoly dollars) and \(x\) represents the distance (in number of spaces). 


The model shows that as the distance from “Go” increases, the price of the property increases.

The slope of the equation of the linear model is 8. This means that for every space from “Go,” the price of the property increases $8. 

Notice this gives an estimate. The most expensive property is 39 spaces from “Go” and costs $400. The model would give the price to be \(y=8(39)+40\) or $352.

The model gives a difference of $48 between the estimated price using the model and the actual price.

Try It: Using Linear Models

Looking at the linear model above, what claim can be made?

Enter your answer here.

Compare your answer:

Here is one claim that can be made looking at the scatter plot and linear model:

As the mean July temperature of a city increases, so does the mean rainfall per year.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 3.1.5: Using an Equation for a Fit Line
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The scatter plot shows the maximum noise level when different numbers of people are in a stadium. The linear model is given by the equation \(y = 1.5x + 22.7\), where \(y\) represents maximum noise level and \(x\) represents the number of people, in thousands, in the stadium.

\(y = 1.5x + 22.7\)



  1. The slope of the linear model is 1.5. What does this mean in terms of the maximum noise level and the number of people?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

For every additional thousand people in the stadium, the noise level increases by about 1.5 decibels.




  1. A sports announcer states that there are 65,000 fans in the stadium. Estimate the maximum noise level. Is this estimate reasonable? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

120.2 decibels. Sample reasoning: It is a reasonable value since the data seem to fit a linear model well, so it is probably near this value.




  1. What is the \(y\)-intercept of the linear model given? What does it mean in the context of the problem? Is this reasonable? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,22.7)\), which means a stadium with no people in it will have a maximum noise level of 22.7 decibels. Sample reasonings:

  • This is actually reasonable since a whisper is about 20 decibels.
  • This is not reasonable since it should be silent with no people in the stadium.
  • This is not reasonable because the point is so far from the data that it is unlikely that the linear model will be accurate.

page.title: 3.1.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. The scatter plot shows the number of times a player came to bat and the number of hits they had.


The scatter plot includes a point at \((318,80)\). Describe the meaning of this point in this situation.

Correct! For every 318 at bats, there are 80 hits.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is that for every 318 at bats, there are 80 hits. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. The scatter plot shows the number of minutes people had to wait for service at a restaurant and the number of waitstaff available at the time.


A line that models the data is given by the equation \(y=-1.62x+18\), where \(y\) represents the wait time, and \(x\) represents the number of waitstaff available.

  1. The slope of the line is \(-1.62\). What does this mean in this situation?

Correct! The slope means that for every increase of 1 staff person, the wait time decreases 1.62 minutes.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the slope means that for every increase of 1 staff person, the wait time decreases 1.62 minutes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

     b. The slope of the line is \(-1.62\). Is it realistic to conclude, for this slope, as \(x\) increases, \(y\) will decrease?

Correct! Yes. For every increase of staff people, \(x\), the wait time, \(y\), decreases. For an increase of 1 staff person, the wait time decreases 1.62 minutes. This is realistic.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Yes. For every increase of staff people, \(x\), the wait time, \(y\), decreases. For an increase of 1 staff person, the wait time decreases 1.62 minutes. This is realistic. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

     c. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,18)\). What does this mean in this situation?

Correct! When there are 0 staff people, the wait time is 18 minutes. This is not realistic when there are no staff available.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is when there are 0 staff people, the wait time is 18 minutes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

      d. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,18)\). Is this a realistic \(y\)-intercept point if \(y\) represents the wait time and \(x\) represents the number of staff available?

Correct! No, this is not realistic when there are no staff available.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: No, this is not realistic when there are no staff available. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. The company’s pricing plan states that the usage rate is constant for any number of minutes connected to the Internet. The number of minutes is related to the cost in dollars and has a linear relationship. The equation of the line is \(y = 0.03x +0.10\). What does the slope represent in this situation?

Correct! For every minute of Internet usage, the price increases 3 cents.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is for every minute of Internet used, the price increases 3 cents. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Below is a scatter plot of the data with two linear models, \(y=130-5x\) and \(y=25.3+3.66x\). Which of these two models does a better job of describing how shoe length \(x\) and height \(y\) are related? Explain your choice. 

Correct! The line of \(y = 25.3 + 3.66x\) is a better choice because as shoe length increases, height tends to increase.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the line of \(y = 25.3 + 3.66x\) is a better choice because as shoe length increases, height tends to increase. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. The scatter plot below displays the elevation and mean number of clear days per year of 14 U.S. cities. Two lines are shown on the scatter plot. Which line fits the data better?

Correct! Line 2 fits the data better because more points seem to be closer to the line.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 3.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Line 2 fits the data better because more points seem to be closer to the line. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. According to the scatter plot below, what claim can be made about women’s shoe length and height?

Correct! As a woman’s shoe length increases, her height also tends to increase.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: As a woman’s shoe length increases, her height also tends to increase. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 7–9, use the scatter plot below.

This scatter plot shows foal birth weight and mare’s weight.


7. What does the slope mean of a linear model on this scatter plot?

Correct! The slope represents the increase in foal weight in kg for each kg increase in mare weight

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.1.2–3.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the slope represents the increase in foal weight in kg for each kg increase in mare weight. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Will the \(y\)-intercept of a linear model make sense in this problem?

Correct! No. When the mare weight is zero, the linear model will be above 0 on the \(y\)-axis.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 3.1.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: No. When the mare weight is zero, the linear model will be above 0 on the \(y\)-axis. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. What does the point \((548, 108)\) mean in this problem?

Correct! A mare weighing 548 kg weighed 108 kg as a foal.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 3.1.2–3.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is that a mare weighing 548 kg weighed 108 kg as a foal. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 3.1.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the rate of change and \(y\)-intercept for a linear model in everyday language.
  • Draw a linear model that fits the data well and use the linear model to estimate values.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 3.1.1: Exploring Scatter Plots
    • In this activity, you recalled information about scatter plots, which was used when you expanded your understanding in a later activity. You noticed and wondered many things about the images, the relationship between the number of people and the maximum noise level, interpreting the line of best fit, and general information about scatter plots.
  • 3.1.2: Creating a Scatter Plot Using Data
    • In this activity, you created a scatter plot from data given in context to interpret the slope and vertical intercept of the linear model and to use the linear model to make predictions.
  • 3.1.2: Self Check 
  • 3.1.3: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Linear Model 
    • In this activity, you interpreted in context the slope and vertical intercept of a linear model given a scatter plot and the equation for a linear model that fit the data well. The linear model was also used to interpolate and extrapolate information about the data in context.
  • 3.1.3: Self Check 
  • 3.1.4: Interpreting the Slope and Vertical Intercept of a Scatter Plot
    • In this activity, you interpreted the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data. You were given scatter plots for different pairs of variables and the equation of a line of best fit. Then you used the line of best fit and its equation to describe the meaning of the vertical intercept and slope.
  • 3.1.4: Self Check 
  • 3.1.5: Using an Equation for a Fit Line 
    • In this activity, you considered that we have to look at axes and demonstrate the usefulness of using an equation for a fit line, rather than sketching on a graph, to determine if the slope and \(y\)-intercept make sense for the linear model in the context of the problem.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 3.1.6: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
